page.title: 01HUTTON-IN-THE-FOREST
page.content:
The mediaeval Forest of Inglewood stretched for 15 miles south from Carlisle on the west side of the river Eden. It was composed of open country as well as woodland, and was administered direct by the Crown under the Forest Law, serving as a base for the English in their wars against the Scots and providing them with food, and space to assemble, exercise and plan behind the area of conflict.
Hutton was one of the most southerly manors in the Forest and as Lord of the Manor, Lord Inglewood is still charged with the duty of "holding the King's stirrup when he mounts his horse in the Castle of Carlisle".
The present Lord Inglewood is William Morgan Fletcher Vane, 1st Baron Inglewood, born 1909.
